questions.text: A patient presents with a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals. Which stage of syphilis does this presentation indicate, and what is the recommended medical treatment?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Primary syphilis, Benzath

Stage of Syphilis

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Diagnostic Features

Treatment

Primary Syphilis (Hard chancre)
  • Single painless ulcer (chancre) at the site of infection
  • Clean base and indurated (hard) borders
  • Highly infectious

  • B/L enlarged inguinal lymph nodes (Rubbery consistency)
  • Genital, anal, or oral chancre
  • Painless and may go unnoticed
  • Occurs 10-90 days after infection
  • Dark-field microscopy of exudate from chancre
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  •  Benzathine penicillin G (IM) 2.4 million units single dose.
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Widespread rash (maculopapular or pustular)
  • Fever, malaise, headache, sore throat
  • Lymphadenopathy (Characteristic - Epitrochlear group of lymph nodes)
  • Mucous membrane lesions
  • Moth eaten alopecia
  • Rash involving the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • Condylomata lata (moist, flat-topped papules) in warm, moist areas
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Elevated liver enzymes, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) 

    2.4 million units single dose

Latent Syphilis
  • Asymptomatic
  • Early latent (within 1 year of infection) or late latent (more than 1 year after infection)
  • No visible symptoms
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM)
  • 2.4 million units single dose for early latent and 2.4 million units three doses once weekly for late latent syphilis.

Tertiary Syphilis
  • Late-stage complications affecting multiple organs
  • Gummas (soft, non-cancerous growths)
  • Cardiovascular syphilis (aortitis, aortic aneurysms)
  • Neurosyphilis (meningitis, paresis, tabes dorsalis)
  • Diverse clinical manifestations
  • Gummas in skin, bones, and internal organs
  • Neurological deficits, psychiatric symptoms
  • Aortic aneurysms, valvular insufficiencies
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities (if neurosyphilis suspected)
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) or Penicillin G (IV/IM) for neurosyphilis

Congenital Syphilis
  • Transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy
  • Various manifestations (hepatosplenomegaly, rash, bone deformities, Hutchinson teeth, saddle nose)
  • Infected infants at birth or develop symptoms within the first few months of life
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR) in the infant or mother
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) for infants and pregnant mothers

questions.text: What is the hallmark feature of Guerin's fracture?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- Hanging palate and teeth

Lefort 1 fracture/Guerin’s fracture/Transverse fracture

 
  • Fracture line runs from the floor of the nose to the floor of the maxillary sinus.
  • Hallmark feature: Hanging palate and hanging teeth.
  • The fracture line is horizontal.
  • Guerin’s sign: Bluish discoloration of palate due to greater palatine artery rupture.
  • It is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

Lefort 2 fracture/Pyramidal fracture

 
  • Fracture line goes from nasion via the lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, and then to the maxilla.
  • Hallmark feature: Hanging maxilla.
  • CSF rhinorrhea may or may not be associated.

Lefort 3 fracture/ Craniofacial dysfunction
  • Fracture line goes from the nasion, medial wall of the orbit, lateral wall of the orbit, floor of the orbit, and zygoma.
  • High risk of CSF rhinorrhea.

Indications of Adrenaline
1. Cardiac arrest
2. Anaphylaxis
3. Severe asthma exacerbation not responding to other treatments
4. Symptomatic bradycardia refractory to atropine
5. Severe hypotension/shock
6. Local vasoconstriction in hemorrhage control (e.g., epistaxis)
7. Adjunct in local anesthesia to prolong duration and reduce bleeding
8. Intraosseous infusion during resuscitation when IV access is not feasible
9. As a bronchodilator in croup
10. Intraocular administration for pupillary dilation during eye exams or surgery

questions.text: A 40-year-old gardener presents to the dermatology clinic with painless, nodular skin lesions on his leg. He recalls being pricked by a thorn while working in the garden a few weeks ago. Examination findings are shown below: There is no evidence of surrounding redness or inflammation. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- Sporotrich

Sporotrichosis

 

Causative Agent

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in soil and decaying vegetation.

Epidemiology

Worldwide distribution, more common in tropical and subtropical regions. Occupational risk for those involved in outdoor activities.

Transmission

It usually results from the fungus's traumatic inoculation of the skin (e.g., via thorns, splinters, or cuts). In rare cases, it can also occur through inhalation.

Clinical Forms

1. Cutaneous Sporotrichosis: Most common form, characterized by nodular or ulcerative lesions along the lymphatic channels.

2. Lymphocutaneous Sporotrichosis: Extension of infection along lymphatic vessels, forming a chain of nodules.

3. Extracutaneous Sporotrichosis: Involves other organs (rare).

Diagnosis

1. Fungal Culture: Growth of Sporothrix schenckii from clinical specimens.

2. Microscopic Examination: Detection of yeast forms in tissue.

Treatment

Itraconazole is the first-line antifungal agent.

Other options include potassium iodide or, in severe cases, amphotericin B

Prevention

Avoidance of traumatic injuries in environments where the fungus is present, especially for individuals at higher risk (e.g., gardeners and farmers).

Complications

Dissemination to other organs (rare). Chronic or severe cases may require prolonged antifungal therapy.

Prognosis

Generally good with appropriate treatment, but severe or disseminated cases may have a more guarded prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is considered an absolute indication of tonsillectomy ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Obstructive sleep apnea:

Absolute indications

Relative indications
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
    • Enlarged tonsils and enlarged adenoids usually coexist in children which leads to airway obstruction. When the child goes to sleep, the tongue falls back (loss of tone during sleep) leading to further airway obstruction & cessation of breathing for 10 seconds or more (apnea)
    • This condition predisposes the child to chronic hypoxia, leading to pulmonary artery hypertension which in turn leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Malignancy of the tonsil
  • Recurrent tonsillitis
  • 2nd attack of quinsy / peritonsillar abscess
  • Chronic tonsillitis
  • Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures, cardiac disease, IgA nephropathy
  • Non – tonsillar indications (The tonsil is removed as a part of another surgery): Excision of the styloid process and UPPP (uvulopalatopharyngoplasty).

Absolute indications

Relative indications
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
    • Enlarged tonsils and enlarged adenoids usually coexist in children which leads to airway obstruction. When the child goes to sleep, the tongue falls back (loss of tone during sleep) leading to further airway obstruction & cessation of breathing for 10 seconds or more (apnea)
    • This condition predisposes the child to chronic hypoxia leading to pulmonary artery hypertension which in turn leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Malignancy of the tonsil
  • Recurrent tonsillitis
  • 2nd attack of quinsy / peritonsillar abscess
  • Chronic tonsillitis
  • Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures, cardiac disease, IgA nephropathy
  • Non – tonsillar indications (The tonsil is removed as a part of the another surgery): Excision of the styloid process and UPPP (uvulopalatopharyngoplasty).

Absolute Contraindications

Relative Contraindications
  • Polio epidemic
  • Submucous cleft (due to velopharyngeal insufficiency)
  • Acute tonsillar infection
  • The age of the child is <3 years
  • Recent acute upper respiratory tract infection

questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- M

Cell Type

Embryology

Function

Keratinocytes

Arise from the ectoderm during embryonic development.

Produce keratin, which provides structural integrity to the skin.

Melanocytes

Derived from neural crest cells during embryogenesis.

Produce melanin, responsible for skin pigmentation and UV protection.

Langerhans Cells

Originate from bone marrow-derived monocytes and migrate to the epidermis during fetal development.

Act as antigen-presenting cells (APCs) in the skin's immune defense.

Merkel Cells

Develop from neural crest cells during embryonic development.

Function as touch receptors in the skin, forming Merkel cell-neurite complexes.

questions.text: Mark, a 35-year-old man, has been referred to a psychiatrist by his family due to his increasingly unusual behavior and beliefs. His family reports that Mark has become convinced that his co-workers, neighbors, and even random strangers he encounters on the street are all the same person in disguise. He believes that this individual is stalking him and trying to harm him. Mark's family is concerned about his safety and well-being and wants to understand his condition better.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A:  Freg

  Fregoli Syndrome/Fregoli delusion/Fregoli's illusion
Definition A rare psychological disorder characterized by a delusional belief that different people are, in fact, a single person who changes appearance or is in disguise.
Named After Named after the Italian actor Leopoldo Fregoli, known for his quick costume changes, which is often related to the delusion.
Perception Individuals with Fregoli syndrome perceive that different people are actually a single person who changes appearance to deceive and persecute them.
Hallucinations Fregoli syndrome can be associated with auditory or visual hallucinations related to perceived disguises or impersonations.
Causes The exact cause is not well understood, but it is often associated with neurological or psychiatric conditions, including schizophrenia, brain injuries, and other cognitive disorders.
Diagnosis Diagnosis is typically made through psychiatric evaluation and consideration of the patient's delusional beliefs and behavior.
Treatment Treatment may involve antipsychotic medications, psychotherapy, and support for any underlying psychiatric or neurological conditions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of chronic excessive alcohol use is brought to the emergency department by her family. They report that she has been confused and has had difficulty walking for the past few days. On examination, you note global confusion, horizontal nystagmus, and ataxia . Laboratory tests reveal thiamine deficiency. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B: Wernicke's Encephalopathy

Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

Onset

 

Acute

Symptoms

G: Global Confusion

O: Ophthalmoplegia, Horizontal Nystagmus Gaze Palsy

  • 6th nerve Palsy is the most common & 3rd nerve Palsy is the second most common.

A: Ataxia

 

Cause

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) Deficiency

  • Due to poor nutrition.
  • Due to poor absorption of nutrition in chronic alcoholics.

Thiamine is an important cofactor for several enzymes required in

body:

  • Thiamine Pyrophosphate
  • Pyruvate Dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase
  • Transketolase
  • Required for axon potential and transmission in the synapse.

 

Neuropathologic Lesions with symmetrical involving

· Mammillary bodies

· Thalamus, Hypothalamus

· Midbrain

· Pons

· Medulla

· Fornix

· Cerebellum

Treatment
  • Thiamine Supplementation- Rapid response to parenteral Thiamine.
  • Initial dose: 100mg (oral- 2-3 times a day) for 1-2 weeks

Reversible condition

  • Ophthalmoplegia reversed within hours of Thiamine supplementation.
  • Residual ataxia remains despite treatment in a small percentage of cases.
  • For patients with alcohol-related disorders, receiving IV- Glucose solution, it is always a good practice to add 100 mg of Thiamine in each liter of glucose.
  • In alcohol disorder-related patients receiving IV glucose, glucose is utilized against Thiamine as a cofactor and those enzymes are utilized and may precipitate Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Wernicke's Encephalopathy

Onset

Acute

Symptoms
  • Global Confusion (G)
  • Ophthalmoplegia (O)
  • Ataxia (A)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Affected Brain Areas
  • Mammillary bodies
  • Thalamus
  • Midline cerebellum

Treatment for Thiamine Deficiency

Details

Treatment

Thiamine Supplementation

Administration

Parenteral Thiamine (IV)

Initial Dose

100 mg

Duration

1-2 weeks

Dosage (Oral)

100 mg, 2-3 times a day

Rapid Response

Ophthalmoplegia reversal within hours

Residual Ataxia

Some cases may have residual ataxia

Thiamine with IV Glucose Solution

Add 100 mg Thiamine to each litre of glucose

questions.explanation:
Correct Option C -

Epinephrine use

Dose and route

Rationale

Anaphylaxis (DOC)

0.5 ml of 1:1000 – IM route (Vastus lateralis)
  • Epinephrine stimulates b2 receptors – causing bronchodilation
  • Inhibits histamine release from muscles

Brittle asthma (sudden emergency in asthma)

0.5 ml of 1:1000-IM or SC
  • Epinephrine stimulates b2 receptors – causing bronchodilation
  • Inhibits histamine release from muscles

Cardiac arrest (CPR)

1 ml of 1:1000 – IV or IO or 1 ml of 1:1000 - ET
  • Epinephrine stimulates a1 receptor – produces vasoconstriction and increases venous return to the heart
  • Norepinephrine, dopamine, and vasopressin-also are given in cardiac arrest

During or along with local anesthetics

1:50000 to 1:200000
  • Epinephrine when given locally stimulates a1 receptor – produces vasoconstriction and reduces the absorption of the local anesthetic into blood

questions.text: The body of a 45-year-old male with a known history of HIV infection has been sent for postmortem investigations . What is the best method of organ removal in the autopsy of this case ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Rokinansky meth

Autopsy Techniques   Advantage Disadvantage
Letulle’s

Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • The best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other
  • Rapid technique
 Difficult to handle large mass.

Ghon’s

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks (en block)

 This method can also be used in Infants  

Virchow’s

Organs are removed one by one

 Most commonly used technique (easier to perform) Anatomical relations of organs are not preserved
Rokitansky In situ dissection (inside the body)

Preferred method in:

  • Infected bodies like HIV, and Hepatitis B (prevents spreading of infection)
  • Radiation hazards
  • Fetal brain dissection

Correct Option A - Von Gierk

Disease

Deficient Enzyme

Main Signs/Symptoms

Von Gierke disease  (type I)

Glucose-6-phosphatase

Lactic acidosis, hypoglycemia, hyperuricemia, impaired growth, bone thinning.

Pompe disease (type II)

Acid α-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Excess glycogen in lysosomes, enlarged liver, and heart; muscle weakness and heart problems in severe forms.

Cori disease (type III)

Glycogen debranching enzyme (4:4 transferase)

Enlarged liver, growth delay, fasting hypoglycemia, abnormal glycogen structure, elevated fat in blood, possible muscle weakness.

Andersen disease (type IV)

Glycogen branching enzyme (4:6 transferase)

Growth delay, enlarged liver, myopathy; usually results in death by age 5.

McArdle disease (type V)

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase (myophosphorylase)

Muscle weakness and cramping after exercise; usually a relatively benign, chronic condition.

Hers disease (type VI)

Liver glycogen phosphorylase

Liver enlargement, hypoglycemia, developmental delay.

Tarui disease (type VII)

Muscle phosphofructokinase

Exercise-induced muscle cramps, developmental delay, hemolytic anemia in some cases.

questions.text: A young woman is brought to the emergency room with profuse vomiting and confusion. Examination shows altered mental status. Jamaican vomiting sickness is suspected. Which of the following enzymes is rendered inactive in this case?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Acyl CoA dehydrogenase:

Nonketotic hypoglycemia
  • In hypoglycemia due to a fatty acid oxidation defect, there will be no Acetyl CoA and no ketone bodies.

Hyperammonemia
  • To support fatty acid synthesis, amino acid oxidation takes place, and wherever AAs get oxidized, the amino group will be released as ammonia.

Dicarboxylic aciduria
  • When peroxisomes mediate β-oxidation, they can only oxidize fatty acids up to very short-chain lengths.
  • Consequently, ω-oxidation of very short-chain fatty acids occurs, leading to the production of dicarboxylic acids, which can be detected in urine as dicarboxylic aciduria.
